content:
You are drafting a new Air Force performance bullet from this impact description.

Impact description:
Title: DAF CLOUDworks Azure
Date: 9/30/2025
Actions: Designed, built, and accredited the DAF CLOUDworks enterprise Azure cloud across Unclassified, SIPR, and JWICS networks from the ground up; led the end-to-end architecture, security design, accreditation strategy, and execution, achieving full three-year ATO in 8 months and complete operational delivery in one year—the fastest enterprise IC cloud accreditation on record.
Impact: Delivered the Air Force Intelligence Community’s first inheritable, continuously monitored Azure ATO, allowing mission partners to deploy instant compliant landing zones and eliminate 6–18 months of independent ATO delays. Enabled architectural freedom for mission teams under pre-configured AF IC cybersecurity guardrails, radically accelerating warfighter speed, cloud adoption, and operational scaling.
Metrics: •	$8.742M/year Azure engineering labor (30 FTE contractors) 	•	$844K/year Azure hub cloud infrastructure 	•	3 security domains: Unclassified, SIPR, JWICS 	•	Founding stakeholders: Space Force, CENTCOM 	•	Mission partners: SOCOM, AFOTEC, ACC A3/2D 	•	Industry partner: Microsoft Azure 	•	ATO timeline: 8 months (record), 3-year duration 	•	Program Status: Fully transitioned to DAF CLOUDworks Program of Record 	•	Operational: Yes (active production use)
Notes: This was the first instance of a single, enterprise-scale, inheritable Azure ATO in the Air Force IC with continuous monitoring enabled at Day 1. Built without central funding—entirely sustained through external customer investment. The solution permanently removed ATO as the pacing item for classified cloud onboarding and enabled mission-driven, not architecture-restricted, development.

Return exactly three bullets, each <= 215 characters.

Bullet mode: "Award (215)" (target: 215 chars).
Always keep suggestions within the character limit for the selected mode.

IMPORTANT: Each bullet option MUST start with "- " (dash followed by space). For example: "- Led DAF CLOUDworks..."
The "- " prefix is part of the bullet format and should be included in the character count.

=== USER REQUEST ===
Please provide me the first bullet options for this

- Built/accredited DAF CLOUDworks Azure across Unclass/SIPR/JWICS; led arch + security; earned 3‑yr ATO in 8 months (IC record) & full ops in 1 year—unlocked inheritable, Day‑1 CM ATO for instant onboarding.
- Delivered AF IC’s first inheritable, Day‑1 CM Azure ATO; led end‑to‑end arch + accreditation to 3‑yr ATO in 8 months—instant compliant LZs; eliminates 6–18 months per mission ATO delay.
- Launched enterprise Azure for AF IC from zero; 3 domains, 30 FTE; no central funds; secured 3‑yr ATO in 8 months—now an operational PoR accelerating cloud adoption and warfighter speed across Space Force/CENTCOM.

You are iterating on an existing Air Force performance bullet.

Current bullet:
"- Delivered AF IC’s first inheritable ATO; led end‑to‑end arch + accreditation to 3‑yr ATO in 8 months—instant compliant LZs; eliminates 6–18 months per mission ATO delay."

Return exactly three improved versions of this bullet, each <= 215 characters, preserving the same facts and metrics.
Focus on clarity, impact, and staying within the 215-character limit.

Bullet mode: "Award (215)" (target: 215 chars).
Always keep suggestions within the character limit for the selected mode.

IMPORTANT: Each bullet option MUST start with "- " (dash followed by space). For example: "- Led DAF CLOUDworks..."
The "- " prefix is part of the bullet format and should be included in the character count.

=== USER REQUEST ===
The ATO is a single-ATO that mission partners automatically inherit as they're onboarded. I like this "secured 3‑yr ATO in 8 months". I think we should include the dollar figures for the labor and cloud costs.

- Delivered AF IC’s first single, inheritable ATO—auto‑applied at onboarding; led arch/accred; secured 3‑yr ATO in 8 months; instant compliant LZs; cuts 6–18 mo/mission; $8.742M/yr labor, $844K/yr cloud.
- Led end‑to‑end arch/accred for AF IC’s first single, inheritable ATO—auto‑inherited at onboarding; secured 3‑yr ATO in 8 months; instant compliant LZs; saves 6–18 mo/mission; $8.742M/yr labor; $844K/yr cloud.
- Delivered AF IC’s first single, inheritable Azure ATO—auto‑inherited at onboarding; secured 3‑yr ATO in 8 months; instant compliant LZs; removes 6–18 mo/mission ATO waits; $8.742M/yr labor; $844K/yr hub cloud.

content:
You are iterating on an existing Air Force performance bullet.

Current bullet:
"Directed 92d COS CPT engagement during major cyber event as DAF CLOUDworks Acting Dir—earned external validation of mature cloud defenses with zero Critical/High/Medium findings"

Return exactly three improved versions of this bullet, each <= 250 characters, preserving the same facts and metrics.
Focus on clarity, impact, and staying within the 250-character limit.

Bullet mode: "OPB 250" (target: 250 chars).
Always keep suggestions within the character limit for the selected mode.

=== USER REQUEST ===
Here's more information: "Facilitated a multi-day collaborative effort with a threat hunt team which resulted in no critical/High/Medium security findings. Created cross-functional collaboration that broke down silos between program and hunt teams, with both sides identifying growth opportunities for future cloud security partnerships." And from a rollup email: BLUF: The 92d Cyberspace Operations Squadron's Cyber Protection Team (CPT) confirms DAF CLOUDworks is cybersecure. No malicious activity found.

 

 

Col Somann,

 

The 92d COS CPT (the military team that came to Rome) completed its investigation into the "cybersecurity incident" identified by 16AF. No malicious activity or compromise was found. The team has departed Rome and returned to their home station.

 

Key Findings:

Conducted an in-depth review of our logs - no issues or malicious activity detected.
Confirmed previously flagged logs were benign background internet connections.
Noted this is the largest cloud environment they've assessed to date.
Will include several hardening recommendations in their final report.
Retaining Kibana access temporarily for follow-up review; will remove access once the report is finalized.

- Directed 92d COS CPT during major cyber event as DAF CLOUDworks Acting Dir—external validation: zero Critical/High/Medium findings; no malicious activity/compromise; largest cloud they've assessed; hardened with follow-on recs.
- Facilitated multi-day 92d COS CPT hunt during major cyber event as DAF CLOUDworks Acting Dir—broke silos; log review confirmed benign flags; zero Critical/High/Medium findings; captured hardening recs; temp Kibana access.
- Directed 92d COS CPT engagement amid major cyber event as DAF CLOUDworks Acting Dir—validated: no malicious activity or compromise; zero Critical/High/Medium findings; largest cloud they assessed; strengthened partnerships.

- As DAF CLOUDworks Acting Dir, facilitated 92d COS CPT assessment amid major cyber event—log review confirmed no malicious activity; external validation: zero Critical/High/Medium findings; follow‑on hardening recs.

content:
You are iterating on an existing Air Force performance bullet.

Current bullet:
"- Led the HAF AF/A2 response for a HASC RFI; enabled accurate congressional oversight of IC JWCC and C2E cloud contract usage, funding, and manpower; protected DAF and IC credibility at congressional levels"

Return exactly three improved versions of this bullet, each <= 250 characters, preserving the same facts and metrics.
Focus on clarity, impact, and staying within the 250-character limit.

Bullet mode: "OPB 250" (target: 250 chars).
Always keep suggestions within the character limit for the selected mode.

=== USER REQUEST ===
Here's the email chain, please make this bullet better: HASC Cloud RFI --Due 1 Oct 25
NICHOLS, GLORIA C Lt Col USAF HAF AF/A2OI
Wed 01-Oct-25 16:07
Thanks! I can take it from there, appreciate the quick turn. V/R, Lt Col Nichols GLORIA C. NICHOLS, Lt Col, USAF Lead, Air Force Intelligence Cloud Portfolio AF/A2OI Pentagon – 5E1049 Comm: 703-695-6666
HOTALING, ERIK T CTR USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA
​PECK, CHRISTOPHER S Maj USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA;​NICHOLS, GLORIA C Lt Col USAF HAF AF/A2OI​
​BERTHELSEN, WALTER J 2d Lt USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA;​VANDERHOOF, ANDREW J CIV USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA;​LAMPERT, BENJAMIN J CIV USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA​
Good afternoon Lt Col Nichols,

 

Answer in red below

 

1. Scene Setting:

- What major contract vehicles is the DAF using for cloud procurement (to include, I believe, JWCC and Cloud One)? DAF Cw utilizing C2E.  We do have three Mission partners who have utilized JWCC for their own Cloud Capacity, managed by themselves.

- What is the relative size of these contracts (workloads, cost, programs supported, etc.)? Vary greatly on specific demand.  It is all based on cloud consumption and Professional Services (labor) estimates ranging up to $20M dollars. DAF Cw utilizes and supports many C2E task orders a year. 

- Is the scope of these contracts different? If so, how? I believe the only different between JWCC and C2E from a scope perspective is one is for the IC (C2E) and one if for the DoW (JWCC)

- How has the DAF decided between which contract vehicle to use? We are in the IC, we only utilize C2E.  Again, several Mission Partners do utilize JWCC, and they are associated with DoW.

 

2. Personnel:

- How many personnel is the DAF dedicating to navigating cloud procurement and management? For managing our own C2E Task Orders, we have 6 .  DAF Cw has ~250 people that manage the enterprise cloud environment.

- What is the delta in filled billets from Jan 2025 to present day for these cloud procurement offices? DAF Cw would welcome any additional billets to support the expansion of the program.  I do not know how many billets are associated specifically to DAF Cw, I would lean on your knowledge as Andrew may be the only one to answer that.

 

3. Transition from Cloud One > JWCC > JWCC Next

- Is there work performed under the Cloud One contract today that is not within JWCC scope? N/A We use C2E

- Are there any concerns around the number of personnel that will navigate transitions to JWCC and to JWCC Next in 2027? N/A

- How is the DAF ensuring mission continuity as these cloud contracts change? Are there concerns that these potential disruptions will cause risk to mission? N/A we don’t use JWCC

- How is cost expected to change with transitions to JWCC and JWCC Next? N/A we don’t use JWCC

 

Questions under 3 are asked under an assumption that the DAF is moving Cloud One workloads to JWCC and then to JWCC Next. Please correct this assumption if it is not correct or only partially correct. Please also provide any details you deem necessary to help HASC PSMs better understand DAF cloud usage. 

 

 

Erik T Hotaling

 

InSITE SETA Support-Program Analyst

DAF Cw SETA Support-Program Analyst

Air Force Research Laboratory/RIEBA

525 Brooks Road

Rome, NY 13441-4505

Phone: 315-330-2215

Cell: 315-382-5324

DSN: 587-2215

Email: erik.hotaling.ctr@us.af.mil

SIPR: Erik.t.hotaling.ctr@mail.smil.mil

JWICS: erik.hotaling_CTR@af.ic.gov


PECK, CHRISTOPHER S Maj USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA
​HOTALING, ERIK T CTR USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA​
​BERTHELSEN, WALTER J 2d Lt USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA​
Erik,

 

Were you working this for Andrew?

 

 

Christopher “Magic” Peck, Maj, USAF

Acting Director, DAF CLOUDworks

SIPR: christopher.s.peck8.mil@mail.smil.mil

JWICS: christopher.peck@af.ic.gov

Office: 315-330-2305 / Mobile: 315-240-0754

Intelink - DAF CLOUDworks

Intelink - Joint Cloud

NICHOLS, GLORIA C Lt Col USAF HAF AF/A2OI
​PECK, CHRISTOPHER S Maj USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA​
​MARINACK, BAMBI L MSgt USAF HAF AF/A2OI;​HARMON, NORAH G CTR USAF HAF AF/A2OI;​CORYELL, WILLIAM F CTR USAF HAF AF/AF2OI​
Maj Peck,

 

Below is the email chain with the request from HASC. I’m sitting in for Col Jordan right now so I’m about to head out to a meeting that’s scheduled to go from1430-1700. Really hoping it doesn’t take that long, but please coordinate with the CC’d members of our office to provide the details necessary to answer the RFI.

 

I know Andrew forwarded it along to someone to help out with, but not sure who, maybe Erik Hotaling?

 

Thanks!

 

V/R,

 

Lt Col Nichols

 

GLORIA C. NICHOLS, Lt Col, USAF

Lead, Air Force Intelligence Cloud Portfolio

AF/A2OI

 

Pentagon – 5E1049

Comm: 703-695-6666

From: NICHOLS, GLORIA C Lt Col USAF HAF AF/A2OI
Sent: Tuesday, September 30, 2025 10:51 AM
To: LAMPERT, BENJAMIN J CIV USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA <benjamin.lampert.1@us.af.mil>; VANDERHOOF, ANDREW J CIV USAF AFMC AFRL/RIEBA <andrew.vanderhoof@us.af.mil>
Cc: MARINACK, BAMBI L MSgt USAF HAF AF/A2OI <bambi.marinack@us.af.mil>; HARMON, NORAH G CTR USAF HAF AF/A2OI <norah.harmon.ctr@us.af.mil>
Subject: HASC Cloud RFI --Due 1 Oct 25
Importance: High

 

Andrew and Ben,

 

Email chain on the HASC RFI I mentioned on MM is below. Primary questions are:

 

1. Scene Setting:

- What major contract vehicles is the DAF using for cloud procurement (to include, I believe, JWCC and Cloud One)?

- What is the relative size of these contracts (workloads, cost, programs supported, etc.)?

- Is the scope of these contracts different? If so, how?

- How has the DAF decided between which contract vehicle to use?

 

2. Personnel:

- How many personnel is the DAF dedicating to navigating cloud procurement and management?

- What is the delta in filled billets from Jan 2025 to present day for these cloud procurement offices?

 

3. Transition from Cloud One > JWCC > JWCC Next

- Is there work performed under the Cloud One contract today that is not within JWCC scope?

- Are there any concerns around the number of personnel that will navigate transitions to JWCC and to JWCC Next in 2027?

- How is the DAF ensuring mission continuity as these cloud contracts change? Are there concerns that these potential disruptions will cause risk to mission?

- How is cost expected to change with transitions to JWCC and JWCC Next?

 

Questions under 3 are asked under an assumption that the DAF is moving Cloud One workloads to JWCC and then to JWCC Next. Please correct this assumption if it is not correct or only partially correct. Please also provide any details you deem necessary to help HASC PSMs better understand DAF cloud usage.

 

Let me know who else we need to add in from the DAF Cw team to make sure we get the correct answers.

 

V/R,

 

Lt Col Nichols

Cc: HARDIMAN, KEITH L SES USAF AFDW AF/SAF/CN <keith.hardiman@us.af.mil>; MCQUITERY, CORNITA L Lt Col USAF HAF SAF/CN <cornita.mcquitery@us.af.mil>; NIRO, ARIANNA C Maj USAF HAF SAF/CN <arianna.niro.1@us.af.mil>; LYKINS, RODNEY D Col USAF HAF AF/CN <rodney.lykins.1@us.af.mil>
Subject: KJSP: HASC Cloud RFI --Due 3 Oct 25

 

Good morning all,

 

See below questions directly form the HASC CITI (Cyber, IT and Innovation) Subcommittee.  Tasker link below.

 

 

 

SAF/LL received an RFI from HASC CITI subcommittee to better understand current DAF Cloud utilization.

 

1. Scene Setting:

- What major contract vehicles is the DAF using for cloud procurement (to include, I believe, JWCC and Cloud One)?

- What is the relative size of these contracts (workloads, cost, programs supported, etc.)?

- Is the scope of these contracts different? If so, how?

- How has the DAF decided between which contract vehicle to use?

 

2. Personnel:

- How many personnel is the DAF dedicating to navigating cloud procurement and management?

- What is the delta in filled billets from Jan 2025 to present day for these cloud procurement offices?

 

3. Transition from Cloud One > JWCC > JWCC Next

- Is there work performed under the Cloud One contract today that is not within JWCC scope?

- Are there any concerns around the number of personnel that will navigate transitions to JWCC and to JWCC Next in 2027?

- How is the DAF ensuring mission continuity as these cloud contracts change? Are there concerns that these potential disruptions will cause risk to mission?

- How is cost expected to change with transitions to JWCC and JWCC Next?

 

Questions under 3 are asked under an assumption that the DAF is moving Cloud One workloads to JWCC and then to JWCC Next. Please correct this assumption if it is not correct or only partially correct. Please also provide any details you deem necessary to help HASC PSMs better understand DAF cloud usage.

 

 

 

LINK:

 

https://haf.etms2.army.mil/main.aspx?etn=ava_tasker&pagetype=entityrecord&id=%7B70489A96-2F9A-F011-A571-005056831B83%7D&appid=26c98fd8-7465-ed11-b784-005056b43308

 

//SIGNED//

LITA D. RAKHRA, Colonel, USAF

Deputy Director of Staff

Office of the DAF Chief Information Officer (SAF/CN)

Cell 253.223.5445 

Lita.rakhra@us.af.mil

- Led HAF AF/A2 response to HASC RFI—corrected JWCC/C2E assumptions; delivered clear IC cloud usage, funding, and manpower data; enabled accurate oversight and protected DAF/IC credibility.
- Directed HAF AF/A2 HASC RFI deliverable—clarified IC reliance on C2E and JWCC roles; provided traceable usage/funding/manpower details; ensured timely, accurate oversight; safeguarded DAF/IC credibility.
- Orchestrated HAF AF/A2 inputs for HASC RFI—produced on‑time, factual IC cloud (JWCC/C2E) usage, funding, and manpower picture; corrected misconceptions; enabled credible congressional oversight; preserved DAF/IC trust.
